repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Useful to e.g. limit the height to the window height, avoiding unnecessary
work. Or to find out how many buffer lines beyond "start_row" take up a
certain number of logical lines (returned in "end_row" and "end_vcol").

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3355,11 +3355,14 @@ nvim_win_text_height({window}, {opts})                *nvim_win_text_height()*
                   â€¢ end_vcol: Ending virtual column index on "end_row",
                     0-based exclusive, rounded up to full screen lines. When
                     omitted include the whole line.
+                  â€¢ max_height: Don't add the height of lines below the row
+                    for which this height is reached.
 
     Return: ~
         Dict containing text height information, with these keys:
         â€¢ all: The total number of screen lines occupied by the range.
         â€¢ fill: The number of diff filler or virtual lines among them.
+        â€¢ end_row: The row for which "max_height" is reached, or "end_row".

comment_data.body: Well because the row where the loop ends is returned in it. I'll change it though, seems less confusing the other way around.
Why is this change include in this PR?
Dirty workspace when starting work on thisðŸ¤·ðŸ». (Check was added in #32766 but can be simplified like this.)

This will use the start of a multi-line fold, but it should be the end instead. I think it should be like this:
```suggestion
    lnum_prev = lnum_next;
```
The `lnum_next` variable may a bit misnamed here, but I can't decided how else to name it, as if I name it `lnum_end` it's too similar to `end_lnum`.
Oh, I may have named it after the `nextp` argument of `plines_win_full()`.

Yeah already considered this and I wasn't sure but I think `lnum` is correct. That sets it to the line which the last calculated height "belongs to" right? I think that is what we want to return in `max`. E.g. that will be the last (foldtext) line visible in a window (considering `start_row == topline`).

But you said at the top comment:
> "what lines take up X height"

Which sounds like it should be the last line of a fold.
May want to calculate and return `end_vcol` as well.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3355,11 +3355,15 @@ nvim_win_text_height({window}, {opts})                *nvim_win_text_height()*
                   â€¢ end_vcol: Ending virtual column index on "end_row",
                     0-based exclusive, rounded up to full screen lines. When
                     omitted include the whole line.
+                  â€¢ max_height: Don't add the height of lines below the row
+                    for which this height is reached.
 
     Return: ~
         Dict containing text height information, with these keys:
         â€¢ all: The total number of screen lines occupied by the range.
         â€¢ fill: The number of diff filler or virtual lines among them.
+        â€¢ end_row: The row for which "max_height" is reached, or "end_row"

comment_data.body: Well technically the last line of a fold doesn't take up any height. It may be more useful to return the last line of a fold but the first line seems less surprising to me.

That'll depend on the use case, but I can't think of a concrete use case that actually uses the `end_row` return value. The current use case in LSP floating preview doesn't use that value. Did you have a use case in mind?

I intend to use it in #27855 to determine the last line in a message window (could also just use `line('w$')` for that presumably but currently the topline isn't yet what it will be when I want to calculate this...).

So yeah a use case is determining what will be the last visible line in a window when the topline is set to `start_row` but currently `topline != start_row`.

either here or in the description, would be valuable to mention this insight:

> Can be used to reduce unnecessary work, or answer question "what lines take up X height?"
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3355,11 +3355,15 @@ nvim_win_text_height({window}, {opts})                *nvim_win_text_height()*
                   â€¢ end_vcol: Ending virtual column index on "end_row",
                     0-based exclusive, rounded up to full screen lines. When
                     omitted include the whole line.
+                  â€¢ max_height: Don't add the height of lines below the row
+                    for which this height is reached.

comment_data.body: nit: aliasing the api functions in tests makes it hard to grep for existing test cases. and doesn't look like it gains much here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -860,6 +839,7 @@ describe('API/win', function()
   end)
 
   describe('text_height', function()
+    local text_height = api.nvim_win_text_height

comment_data.body: Also specify that `end_row` is the first line of a closed fold?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3355,11 +3355,22 @@ nvim_win_text_height({window}, {opts})                *nvim_win_text_height()*
                   â€¢ end_vcol: Ending virtual column index on "end_row",
                     0-based exclusive, rounded up to full screen lines. When
                     omitted include the whole line.
+                  â€¢ max_height: Don't add the height of lines below the row
+                    for which this height is reached. Useful to e.g. limit the
+                    height to the window height, avoiding unnecessary work. Or
+                    to find out how many buffer lines beyond "start_row" take
+                    up a certain number of logical lines (returned in
+                    "end_row" and "end_vcol").
 
     Return: ~
         Dict containing text height information, with these keys:
         â€¢ all: The total number of screen lines occupied by the range.
         â€¢ fill: The number of diff filler or virtual lines among them.
+        â€¢ end_row: The row for which "max_height" is reached, or "end_row"
+          from {opts} if "max_height" isn't reached.
+        â€¢ end_vcol: Number of columns used up by "end_row" to reach
+          "max_height", or if "max_height" isn't reached, either "end_vcol" or
+          the number of columns in "end_row". 0 if "end_row" is a closed fold.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(api): add "max_height" argument to nvim_win_text_height
